reasoning: The critique targets how the essay treats two sub-arguments for optimism (abundance-driven altruism in 2.3.2 vs asymmetric growth/"long views win" in 2.3.3). These are not central to the essay’s main conclusions (skepticism about WAM-convergence; conditional optimism via partial convergence + trade, tempered by threats), so centrality is low-to-moderate. The substantive point—"the same objection (non-altruistic linear preferences) weakens both arguments"—is somewhat right, but the critique overstates the essay’s reliance on 2.3.3: the authors already qualify it heavily and do not treat it as strong evidence of convergence. Thus it only modestly weakens the relevant sub-claims. The critique is mostly clear, focused, and contains little/no filler.
title: The abundance argument is applied inconsistently across altruistic and temporal preferences
